title: Edge Computing
introduction: Edge computing is a distributed computing paradigm that brings computation and data storage closer to the location where it is needed, to improve response times and save bandwidth. It represents a significant shift from the traditional centralized computing model to a more distributed approach.

sections.title: How It Works
sections.content: Edge computing processes data near the source of data generation (like IoT devices) rather than relying on a central data center. This reduces latency and bandwidth usage by processing data locally.

sections.title: Key Benefits
sections.content:
- Reduced latency for time-sensitive applications
- Lower bandwidth usage and costs
- Improved privacy and security through local data processing
- Better reliability with offline capabilities
- Real-time data processing

sections.title: Use Cases
sections.content:
- Autonomous vehicles
- Industrial IoT (IIoT)
- Smart cities
- Healthcare monitoring
- Augmented/Virtual Reality
- Retail and customer experience

sections.title: Challenges
sections.content:
- Security concerns at the edge
- Device management at scale
- Standardization issues
- Integration with existing infrastructure
- Limited computing resources on edge devices

edgeVsCloud.latency: Lower in edge computing due to proximity to data source
edgeVsCloud.bandwidthUsage: Reduced in edge computing as only relevant data is sent to cloud
edgeVsCloud.costStructure: Higher upfront costs for edge, but lower operational costs
